title: A Viewpoint-based Approach for Interaction Graph Analysis
segmentation: Good afternoon everyone.
I'm sitarama Sir and this work was done in collaboration with my advisor, she Wason Parthasarathy at Ohio State University.
So as Kleinberg noted.
Social network datasets give both more and less more.
As in you can observe global phenomena, but it's hard to perform analysis at smaller scales with respect to single nodes or edges.

Many applications we want to target a particular node, either to recommend the product or advertise, or for other applications and for this community based analysis has been useful and there is, you can analyze the community that the node belongs to, but communities tend to abstract local relationships.
That is, all the nodes in the Community may not be as important to the given node as may not have the same importance.
So in this work we consider the problem of extracting a local neighborhood of interest for a given node.
So we want to actually understand the local relationships that exist within that neighborhood, and this will help us observe how the effect of changes in the graph to that particular node.

So we define this neighborhood as the viewpoint neighborhood for a given node as the graph rooted at that particular node containing only the other nodes having some degree of importance with respect to this node and their interconnections.
But for this we need to we need to measure.
We need to know how to measure importance.
An initial solution would be to just use the distance from the source node.
Obviously nodes that are closer to the source are going to be more important to the source node, so this can be computed trivially using a depth limited search.
You can just choose a sub graph consisting of all nodes at reachable at distance less than some key value from the node and the interactions among them.
An example is shown.
We have a graph of eight nodes.
And we have two viewpoint neighborhoods of depth two and we can see that the only node in common is not F. However, this by.
Itself is not enough.
So some problems with this.
So this assumes that all nodes the same distance away should be treated the same, which may not necessarily be true.
If you look at this particular example graph, nodes D&E are both at distance two away from the source S, But we can argue that these nodes are different in terms of the topology.
Node D is connected to almost every other node in the neighborhood, where is.
Nobody is just connected to node B, so one can argue that D is probably more important.
With respect to the source, that node E, the second problem is that this this way of depth based VPN does not take into account hub nodes.

We know that in these graphs there are very high degree nodes which are connected to a large number of other nodes in the graph, and if any of these hub nodes are present at a distance less than K then they will tend to bring in all these other nodes into the neighborhood, which is not very useful.
So from this we can arrive at the criteria that we want to optimize for constructing viewpoint neighborhood.
Firstly, we would like to take the distance into account.
Obviously nodes that are closer to the source are likely to be more important.
The second one we want to consider the local link structure that is a local topology.

So well connected nodes within the local well connected nodes within the neighborhood are obviously more important to the source node, and the third one is we want to discourage the selection of hub nodes since they tend to bloat the neighborhoods by bringing in a lot of nodes which are not very important.
So we develop an activation spread model that can satisfy these criteria to extract a viewpoint neighborhood for a given source node.

So the activation proceeds from the given source, which is assumed to have a budget M. So it distributes this amount among its initial in its initial set of neighbors, activating them, and they continue the activation when a node receives an amount, it retains some amount for itself, and then it propagates the rest to its descendants, and the activation proceeds in a single direction away from the source.

Until the amount becomes lower than the threshold and then all the nodes which have received some amount considered to be part of the neighborhood and the value that is present at each node reflects how important it is with respect to the source.
This model is actually related to the heat diffusion model.
For graphs we have the description in the paper in more detail.
So at each node the distribution is handled by an activation fun.
So next I'll just talk about some activation functions that can be used.
The simplest one is the inverse degree activation.
So here when a node receives an amount from its parent it it retains one by its out degree one by its degree.
I'm sorry and it distributes the rest equally among its descendants.
So this this case is strong in terms of hubs, because hub nodes will have very high degrees.
So by doing this we can ensure that hub nodes will retain very small amounts and the amount they propagate will also be small.
However, this does not implicitly take.
Basically handling structure because we can look at this example graph.

The budget end equally among 2A and B since he has a degree of three, it will retain them by 6 and it will retain little transmitted by 6 two C&D, whereas node B, since it does not have any descendants, will retain them by two, and so node B will actually end up having getting more important than a, which may not necessarily be the best way to do it.
So to handle this, we look at using the betweenness.
So in this case we are interested in local between this, which is with respect to the source.
So we examine the shortest path from the source to all other nodes within the neighborhood, and nodes which have high betweenness will have will be essentially central within the neighborhood.

And so this actually has strong emphasis on link structure because the well connected nodes will end up having high between these values, but it does not naturally handle hubs because hubs will have high betweenness values also.

So we develop certain critical events to characterize the changes that occur.

And the shrink is the reduction in the size.
Continue is when the neighborhood the members membership is the same and the depth is the same.
And the mutate is the opposite of that.
Where there is a significant change in the neighborhood and attract is when nodes move closer to the source and repulses when it moves further away from the source.
And we examine two types of networks.

In the case of the DLP, and there are low continue events.

In the case of Wikipedia, the number of growth was significantly higher than the number of shrinks, and this is because more pages are added to Wikipedia as time goes on, and there are very few deletions so the neighborhoods do not reduce too much and it's also characterized by a large number of continue events and even in terms of attract.
There are the number of attractive ends are very high compared to the number of elements.
So we we can use these piece simple events to construct measures for capturing different types of behavior overtime.

We have developed an activation spread model using different activation functions.
For this purpose.
We have also proposed the present extensions to find VPN for communities as well as groups of nodes, which is in the paper.
I have not talked about it here and we also perform evolutionary analysis as I mentioned to analyze the changes that occur in these neighborhoods overtime.
We have to find some basic events and some measures based on based on those events to capture different types of behavior.
